Problem:
Consider a magnetic field \\( \\vec{B} = B_0 e^{-kt} \\hat{z} \\), acting on a charged particle resulting in the Lorentz force equation \\( \\dot{\\vec{v}} = q (\\vec{v} \\times \\vec{B}) \\). We explore the effects of an applied electric field \\( \\vec{E} = E_0 \\hat{x} \\) as a transformation on the particle's motion.

If a new magnetic field \\( \\vec{B}_1 = B_1 e^{-kt} \\hat{y} \\) is applied as an intervention at a certain time \\( t_1 \\), will the endpoint trajectory of the particle for \\( T > t_1 \\) depend only on the magnetic field \\( \\vec{B} \\) and not on the electric field \\( \\vec{E} \\) or the new magnetic field \\( \\vec{B}_1 \\)?
Explanation: The intervention with a new magnetic field \\( \\vec{B}_1 \\) introduces additional rotational influences, shifting the net Lorentz force direction, and thereby affecting the trajectory. Both the initial and intervening fields' configurations importantly shape the resultant particle path.
